history.content:
Tbh, web and mobile development is something you can learn on your own time (google MEAN stack, session management, read the ios dev guides).  Once you have the 61 series, you have a solid foundation of software development/abstractions to begin learning without the aid of college courses.  The only thing that the 61 series lacks imo, in terms of introductory web/mobile development, are the basic concepts of databases and networking.  Even these however, are simple enough where an entire course (168, 186), is overkill for basic web/mobile apps.

Though, if you are really set on taking courses, I've heard good things about 169.  186 and 168, as I've mentioned, give you a good introduction for core components of web/mobile applications (though 186 mainly focuses on SQL rather than NoSQL, you should research to see what kind of database fits the application you're making).

I'm sure that the web decal and ios decal are good as well, though overhyped/oversubscribed from my experience.  All these things you can learn on your own (with the added benefit that, if you can learn these things on your own, you get better at learning anything on your own, rather than relying on some class you may/may not get into)

Taking a course about Ruby on rails/160 is completely unnecessary imo (can learn RoR or other frameworks on your own/join design clubs/study UI and UX of other apps)

---

You have 'em all. Go for it.

children.subject: Also you could try and join Mobile Developers of Berkeley.

184 might also be useful if you are planning on doing game stuff. 189 comes to mind as well (understanding how to handle massive data and make sense of it). A lot of mobile companies are moving towards AI/ML to understand their userbase better. (Source: interned at a mobile marketing company last summer).
Any other courses that necessary, in the 160s series, 180s. All the course are worth it, but at least, are there some courses more relevant? I have 3 semesters left!

history.content: I'm an EECS, focus on web and mobile development. I haven't take any upper division courses yet. Any recommendations for courses that best for my career path. I only name a few: CS169, CS160, CS 186, Web decal, iOS decal, Ruby on Rails...
history.subject: Courses for web and mobile development!
